@graph.d3f:definition: The isolate tactic creates logical or physical barriers in a system which reduces opportunities for adversaries to create further accesses.
@graph.rdfs:label: Isolate

@graph.d3f:definition: Broadcast isolation restricts the number of computers a host can contact on their LAN.
@graph.rdfs:label: Broadcast Domain Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Permitting only approved domains and their subdomains to be resolved.
@graph.rdfs:label: DNS Allowlisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking DNS Network Traffic based on criteria such as IP address, domain name, or DNS query type.
@graph.rdfs:label: DNS Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Encrypted encapsulation of routable network traffic.
@graph.rdfs:label: Encrypted Tunnels

@graph.d3f:definition: Using a digital signature to authenticate a file before opening.
@graph.rdfs:label: Executable Allowlisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking the execution of files on a host in accordance with defined application policy rules.
@graph.rdfs:label: Executable Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Execution Isolation techniques prevent application processes from accessing non-essential system resources, such as memory, devices, or files.
@graph.rdfs:label: Execution Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a lookup based on the query's domain name value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Forward Resolution Domain Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a DNS lookup's answer's IP address value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Forward Resolution IP Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Preventing one process from writing to the memory space of another process through hardware based address manager implementations.
@graph.rdfs:label: Hardware-based Process Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking the resolution of any subdomain of a specified domain name.
@graph.rdfs:label: Hierarchical Domain Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking DNS queries that are deceptively similar to legitimate domain names.
@graph.rdfs:label: Homoglyph Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Limiting access to computer input/output (IO) ports to restrict unauthorized devices.
@graph.rdfs:label: IO Port Restriction

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting network traffic originating from untrusted networks destined towards a private host or enclave.
@graph.rdfs:label: Inbound Traffic Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Using kernel-level capabilities to isolate processes.
@graph.rdfs:label: Kernel-based Process Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Controlling access to local computer system resources with kernel-level capabilities.
@graph.rdfs:label: Mandatory Access Control

@graph.d3f:definition: Network Isolation techniques prevent network hosts from accessing non-essential system network resources.
@graph.rdfs:label: Network Isolation

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting network traffic originating from a private host or enclave destined towards untrusted networks.
@graph.rdfs:label: Outbound Traffic Filtering

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a reverse DNS lookup's answer's domain name value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Reverse Resolution Domain Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Blocking a reverse lookup based on the query's IP address value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Reverse Resolution IP Denylisting

@graph.d3f:definition: Configuring a kernel to use an allow or deny list to filter kernel api calls.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Call Filtering
